repnme.cdata!:
Georgia - Institution Building Credit,
            Rehabilitation Credit, First and Second Structural
            Adjustment Credits, First and Second Structural Adjustment
            Technical Assistance Credits, and Energy Sector Adjustment
            Credit Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit conveys mixed results compared
            with the Implementation Completion Report's (ICR)
            ratings, as follows: while ratings concur regarding the
            Institution Building Credit (IBC), and the First Structural
            Adjustment Technical Assistance (SALTA) Projects of
            satisfactory outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts, it downgrades the
            Rehabilitation Credit (RCP) project outcome from highly
            satisfactory to satisfactory, upgrading its sustainability
            to substantial; downgrades the Structural Adjustment Credit
            (SAL) Project outcome to moderately unsatisfactory, with
            likely sustainability, but with modest institutional
            development impacts; and, downgrades the Second Structural
            Adjustment Credit (SALII) Project outcome to unsatisfactory,
            and modest institutional development impacts. Ratings of the
            Energy Sector Adjustment Credit (ESAC) Project concur on
            satisfactory outcome and likely sustainability, but the
            audit upgrades institutional development impacts to
            substantial, and, on the Second Structural Adjustment TA
            (SALTAII) Project outcome is downgraded to moderately
            satisfactory, and modest institutional development impacts,
            although sustainability is also likely. Lessons indicate
            that Georgia's weak governance severely limits the
            country's ability to create conditions conducive to
            economic development, and the effective use of development
            assistance, and, that for a country which experienced
            economic collapse, it is incumbent that the Bank give high
            priority to prompt measures that can directly mitigate
            conditions for the poorest. Furthermore, turnover on the
            country team limited program effectiveness, diminishing the
            continuity of the program, and probably constraining the
            Economic and Sector Work (ES W) that was performed,
            suggesting a more robust, timely ESW program would have been
            beneficial to the design of the reform program, while the
            turnover among policy officials hindered reform progress.

repnme.cdata!:
Georgia - Institution Building and
            Structural Adjustment Technical Assistance Credit Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall performance and outcome of
            both the Institutional Building Credit and the Structural
            Adjustment Technical Assistance Credit is satisfactory, as
            the majority of contracts and specific measures were carried
            out, and the major objectives of the projects were achieved
            and assessed to be sustained. Key lessons learned are: a)
            patience with slow developing components can pay off; b)
            counterpart quality - a high level ally backed by a solid
            team of dedicated counterparts can overcome serious
            obstacles; c) consultants transfer skills - it is important
            to make skills transfer an important part of the
            consultant's terms of reference so that the consultant
            knows they are being judged on this goal; d) adequate
            supervision - intensive supervision is a key success factor
            for projects in new member countries; and e) implementation
            flexibility to maximize effectiveness of loan / credit proceeds.

repnme.cdata!:
Georgia - Structural Adjustment Technical
            Assistance Credit Project (SATAC)

abstracts.cdata!:
The primary objective of the Structural
            Adjustment Technical Assistance Credit Project (SATAC) is to
            support the Government's reform program to stabilize
            the economy and create the conditions for a resumption of
            growth and an improvement in living standards. The project
            includes the following components: 1) technical assistance
            in support of privatization and post-privatization; 2)
            financial sector strengthening; 3) social protection reform;
            4) resource mobilization; 5) information dissemination on
            economic reforms; and 6) energy sector reform.

docna.cdata!:
Georgia - Structural Adjustment Technical
            Assistance Credit Project (SATAC)
